title: 114_hr3573
content: Approval required for refugee admission. Section 207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require the President to recommend the number of refugees to be admitted each fiscal year after consultation with Congress. No refugees can be admitted until a joint resolution setting the number is enacted into law. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change "determination" to "recommendation" and "determined" to "recommended." It also requires a recommendation for refugee admissions to be submitted to Congress and prohibits refugee admissions until a joint resolution sets the number allowed. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change "determination" to "recommendation" in subsection (d). SEC. 3. APPROPRIATE CONSULTATION. Section 207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include additional committees in subsections (d)(1) and (e). The House of Representatives' Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations are involved in the amendment of Section 207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 4 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require consultation with the Director of National Intelligence and the Director of the FBI for determining the admissibility of aliens under section 212(a)(3). SEC. 5 prioritizes refugees from Iraq and Syria persecuted based on religion. Beginning in fiscal year 2016 and ending in fiscal year 2020, the President shall prioritize admission of refugees from Iraq or Syria who are members of a persecuted religious minority community. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act on the effectiveness of the refugee screening process in protecting the security of the United States. The report will cover the number of refugees initially deemed admissible but later found inadmissible, recommend federal agencies to be involved in the admissibility process, and identify any issues or gaps in the process. Issues or gaps in the process for determining the admissibility of refugees under such paragraph and recommendations for improving the process to better protect the security of the United States.
